children.subject: Right now, we're not even sure the school would be able to offer an in-person option. The purpose of online is to accommodate international students and those whose family situation might make it hard to travel back and forth during fall. Hence I seriously doubt they'd make the online experience "inferior" in anyway. If anything professors would be assuming that by default people won't come and watch online rather than the other way around given the current situation.

It's just strange to think how this might work, like in a small, participation based classroom setting. Would some of the students be on zoom on the instructor's laptop while the rest of the class is sitting in desks? I guess this could work if the projectors get used to allow the in-person class to see the zoom students, but participating and lag may become an issue, esp. with everyone on the same Airbears network. Or would instructors just have an in-person section and then another virtual section? That seems infeasible bc that's twice the work for instructors... I can see this working for CS classes since many students don't really show up to things even in a normal semester, and multiple TAs means you could have some virtual discussions and some in-person ones. But I plan to take language/other classes next semester too, which may just not work out well with the in-person/online combo, so I'm wondering if I should even try to look for housing...

Im in a similar situation housing wise, but I expect this is a question instructors have yet to deal with. I guess we can only take the school for its word when they say classes will have online option. I was having trouble picturing how this would look, and i certainly hope "online" doesn't mean simply webcasting the in class lecture and posting it online, in the case of smaller participation-based courses...

history.content:
Now that there’s an official directive that all classes will be available online - do we know yet what will be in-person?  Smaller classes?  Discussions?  Exams?  I have a small class in CS 176, will that class be in-person?

I’m trying to find a good excuse to justify living off campus in Berkeley, but I’m having a hard time doing so unless someone gives me a good reason to come back. Money is pretty tight for the moment in my family but on the other hand I’d go nuts if I had to spend another 4 months at home.
history.subject: Status of smaller classes and discussions for Fall
